===Response===
===Response===
â
Laura Flanders described the events as a "[[Bull Connor]] Moment", in reference to the Birmingham, Alabama leader who infamously deployed firehoses and attack dogs against peaceful protestors during the [[American Civil Rights Movement]].<ref>[http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/eyesontheprize/story/07_c.html PBS's Eyes on the Prize segment, including video of Connor.][http://www2.nbc13.com/vtm/news/local/article/bull_connors_tank_returns_to_birmingham/39865/ Connor's Tank Returns to Birmingham]; Laura Flanders, Nov 19, 2011 "Up with Chris Hayes"</ref> University Professor [[Bob Ostertag]] echoed these sentiments in public letter, writing:<ref>[[Bob Ostertag]]. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bob-ostertag/uc-davis-protest_b_1103039.html Militarization of Campus Police], ''[[Huffington Post]]''</ref>
+
Laura Flanders described the events as a "[[Bull Connor]] Moment", in reference to the Birmingham, Alabama leader who infamously deployed firehoses and attack dogs against peaceful protestors during the [[American Civil Rights Movement]].<ref>[http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/eyesontheprize/story/07_c.html PBS's Eyes on the Prize segment, including video of Connor.][http://www2.nbc13.com/vtm/news/local/article/bull_connors_tank_returns_to_birmingham/39865/ Connor's Tank Returns to Birmingham]; Laura Flanders, Nov 19, 2011 "Up with Chris Hayes"</ref> Viewing footage of the events, [[Ron Christie]] described it as "excessive force" saying, "I wouldn't call that ''pepper-spray'', I'd say that was a ''pepper-hose''".
  +
University Professor [[Bob Ostertag]] echoed these sentiments in public letter, writing:<ref>[[Bob Ostertag]]. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bob-ostertag/uc-davis-protest_b_1103039.html Militarization of Campus Police], ''[[Huffington Post]]''</ref>
{{quote|"Chancellor [[Robert J. Birgeneau|Robert Birgeneau]] thus joins the likes of Bull Connor, the notorious segregationist and architect of the violent repression of the civil rights movement in Birmingham, Alabama, as some of the very few people who view the non-violent tactics of Martin Luther King as violent." }}
{{quote|"Chancellor [[Robert J. Birgeneau|Robert Birgeneau]] thus joins the likes of Bull Connor, the notorious segregationist and architect of the violent repression of the civil rights movement in Birmingham, Alabama, as some of the very few people who view the non-violent tactics of Martin Luther King as violent." }}
